newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: UNESCO praises Portugal's stone age art.
newsitem.headline: UNESCO praises Portugal's stone age art.

text.p: The head of UNESCO, Federico Mayor, said on Saturday he hoped an open air collection of stone age art in northern Portugal would join the organisation's "World Heritage" roll of honour.

"I fully back a bid by Foz Coa for World Heritage status," Mayor, head of the U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, said during a visit to the site. He was joined by Spain's King Juan Carlos and Portuguese President Jorge Sampaio.

On show along the banks of Portugal's river Coa, 350 km (220 miles) northeast of Lisbon, are the scratched rock drawings of stone age hunters who inhabited the rolling hills and deep river valleys more than 10,000 years ago.

On Friday, Culture Minister Manuel Maria Carrilho said the Portuguese government would invest three billion escudos ($17 million) to develop the archaeological park at Foz Coa, including the construction of a museum. ($1=175.198 escudos)
